dataset.title: MCR LTER: Coral Reef: Long-term Community Dynamics: Backreef (Lagoon) Corals Annual Survey, ongoing since 2005

abstract.para: This dataset contains the percentage cover of all stony corals (Scleractinia, pooled among genera) and other major groups analyzed from 0.5 x 0.5 m photographic quadrats at the Backreef habitat at the Moorea Coral Reef LTER, French Polynesia. This survey time series began in 2005 and is repeated each year in April. Functional groups counted are: Scleractinian corals, Macroalgae, Crustose Coralline Algae / Bare Space, Soft Corals, Hydrocorals (Millepora), Algal Turf and Sand. The coral community was sampled photographically in all represented habitats surrounding the island: Fringing Reef, Lagoon, and Outer Reef. This dataset contains only Lagoon (Backreef) data (see knb-lter-mcr.4 for the other habitats) and is structured in a repeated-measures protocol to allow a statistical contrast of sites, shores and times. Community structure was determined through a coarse analysis of the benthic community, initially completed in situ (2005), but using photoquadrats from 2006. There are quadrats analyzed at each of five areas within each site, and the areas are revisited (but not the quadrats) each year to support the repeated measures design. There are two tables available, providing different views of the same data: a long table having all values in one column and a wide table having a separate column for each observed object. Detailed methods are available in the protocols section.

keywordSet.keyword: Richard B. Gump South Pacific Research Station

intellectualRights.para:
Data collected under the auspices of the MCR LTER are available to the public after primary publication, or at most two years after the completion of the study unless proprietary restrictions are warranted. Use of MCR LTER data is subject to acceptance of the following conditions:
1. The user agrees to provide valid name and contact information prior to downloading online data. This information will be used to contact the user in case of changes to the data, and may also be used by data set authors and MCR LTER project administrators to document data usage.
2. The user agrees to cite the data set author and MCR LTER in all publications in which the data are used, as per the instructions in the data documentation. If no specific instructions are provided in the data documentation, the user is requested to include the following statement: "Data sets were provided by the Moorea Coral Reef Ecosystem LTER, funded by the US National Science Foundation (OCE-0417412)."
3. The user agrees to provide one copy of any manuscript based on MCR LTER data to the data set author prior to submitting it for publication.
4. The user agrees to send two hard copies of any published manuscript based on MCR LTER data to the following address: Dr. Andrew J. Brooks Deputy Program Director, MCR LTER Marine Science Institute University of California Santa Barbara, CA 93106-6150 The user also agrees to send one electronic copy (pdf format) to the following e-mail address: brooks@msi.ucsb.edu
5. Users are prohibited from selling or redistributing any data provided by MCR LTER without explicit prior permission.
6. Users are encouraged to contact original investigators responsible for data. Where appropriate, researchers whose projects are integrally dependent on MCR LTER data are encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators.
7. Extensive efforts are made to ensure that online data are accurate and up to date, but the authors and the MCR LTER will not take responsibility for any errors that may exist in data provided online. Furthermore, the user assumes all responsibility for errors in analysis or judgment resulting from use of the data.
8. Any violation of the terms of this agreement will result in immediate forfeiture of the data and loss of access privileges to other MCR LTER data sets.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: LTER 1 polygon including LTER 0 on north shore

description.para: This is an ongoing dataset. Data are added every year.

section.title: Photoquadrats
section.para: Quantitative high resolution digital images form 2006-present (in situ counts in 2005).

section.title: Sampling
section.para: The sampling strategy was designed to facilitate tests of the effect of time and shore on the coral community structure of the backreef habitats of Moorea. The backreef habitat within the lagoon and may be synonymous with lagoon habitats in other studies. The sampling design was implemented to accommodate the high spatial variation in the lagoon, and therefore quadrats along a transect were not employed. Instead, each site was characterized by 5 randomly selected patches over a spatial scale of ~50m. At each point, a cardinal axis design was implemented where quadrats were sampled along N, S, E and W axes centered on each patch. Each axis was 5 m long, and 5 quadrats (0.5 x 0.5 m) were scattered randomly along the axis; the position is re-randomized each year. This design is a nested, factorial ANOVA experimental design in which shore of Moorea (north, southeast, or southwest) was treated as a fixed factor, site (LTER 1 through LTER 6) as a random factor nested within shore, and time was a repeated measures factor based on five patches at each site. Depending on the analytical goals, the community structure at each patch can be characterized by averaging all 20 quadrats, or the quadrats can be treated as a nested factor in each patch.

All census methods were designed to quantify coral community structure in terms of the dominant constituents of the benthic community - scleractinian corals, macroalgae, crustose coralline algae, sand, algal turf, and millepora.

section.title: Parameters for Photoquadrat Analysis
section.para: For the purpose of analysis of the benthic community, the quadrats are divided into 25 equal squares (5 x 5 cm) and each square is scored for the benthic category (one of 6 categories as above) that dominates (i.e., ≥ 50% cover) that area. The limit of resolution is 4% change in cover. Identification has been done by various graduate students and technicians and the investigator. The images can be analyzed for coral cover at the genus level (as is accomplished in the outer reef and fringe habitats), but currently this analysis is incomplete for the back reef (2008 and 2009 are available).

section.title: Blue Water
section.para: The backreef habitat in the lagoons is relatively shallow. There is a minimum depth needed to position the camera frame over corals and still be under water. When a quadrat is too shallow, the photo may be tilted off horizontal so that part of the photo is open water, called "blue water", instead of benthic cover. This makes the photoquadrat inappropriate for percent cover analysis. For these photoquadrats the code "BW" is entered in place of coral cover percent.

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Biological Sciences, California State University
Department of Biological Sciences, California State University

funding.para: NSF (LTER) MCR I #OCE-0417412, MCR II #OCE-1026851, and MCR IIb #OCE-1236905

dataTable.entityDescription: Photoquadrat analysis results: Percent cover of benthic taxa inlcuding corals by groups of genera. This table contains the same data as the long-format table, reformatted into wide-format.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Year of Observation. Annual surveys are between April 1 to May 15 of each year.
Patch ID number. A patch is analogous to a transect. Each site has 5 patches.
Quadrat ID. Quadrats are numbered either sequentially or on a north, south, east, west plus-sign orientation.

Percent cover of Stony Coral in photoquadrat. Stony Coral is the sum of Acanthastrea, Acropora, Astreopora, Cyphastrea, Favia, Fungia, Gardinoseris, Herpolitha, Leptastrea, Leptoseris, Lobophyllia, Montastrea, Montipora, Pachyseris, Pavona, Pocillopora, Porites, Psammacora, Sandolitha, Stylocoeniella and Tubastrea.
Percent cover of Macroalgae in photoquadrat. Macroalgae is a functional group.

attribute.id: percent cover Crustose Coralline Algae and Bare Space
attribute.attributeLabel: Percent Crustose Coralline Algae / Bare Space
attribute.attributeDefinition: Percent cover of Crustose Coralline Algae or Bare Space in photoquadrat. Crustose Coralline Algae / Bare Space is a functional group.
Percent cover of Sand in photoquadrat. Sand is a substrate.
Percent cover of Algal Turf in photoquadrat. Turf is a substrate.
Percent cover of Millipora in photoquadrat. Millipora is a genus of Hydrocoral.

Number of square sub-divisions of the quadrat counted. Normally 25, unless sub-squares fell on uncategorized classes. Each class was divided by this total count to get fraction, or x100 to get percent cover.

dataTable.entityDescription: Photoquadrat analysis results: Percent cover of benthic taxa, grouping genera of corals.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Year of Observation. Annual surveys are between April 1 to May 15 of each year.
In the backreef, transects are plus-shaped and called patches. This column is the Patch corresponding to its pole ID
Quadrat number identifies the quadrat. Some quadrats are laid out in a N-S-E-W cross; other patches have quadrats 1 to 10, others 1 to 20.
Taxonomic family, functional group, or substrate.

codeDefinition.definition: Scleractinian coral is a taxonomic order. Also called Stony Coral, it is the sum of Acanthastrea, Acropora, Astreopora, Cyphastrea, Favia, Fungia, Gardinoseris, Herpolitha, Leptastrea, Leptoseris, Lobophyllia, Montastrea, Montipora, Pachyseris, Pavona, Pocillopora, Porites, Psammacora, Sandolitha, Stylocoeniella and Tubastrea.
Crustose Coralline Algae or Bare Space. These are a functional group.
Hydrocorals. Millepora is a genus of coral that is not Scleractinian.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Percent cover in quadrat of this cover class.

ns2:unit.name: dimensionless
ns2:unit.ns2:description: a designation asserting the absence of an associated unit
